Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: ABI Innovation: PlantSimLab: A Simulation Laboratory for Plant Biology
Award.AbstractNarration:
It is increasingly recognized that at the molecular level nonlinear networks of heterogeneous molecules control many plant processes, so that systems biology provides a valuable approach in this field, building on the integration of experimental biology with mathematical modeling. One of the biggest challenges to making this integration a reality is that most plant biologists do not possess the mathematical background needed to build and manipulate mathematical models well enough to use them as tools for hypothesis generation. The goal of the project is to develop a network modeling tool, PlantSimLab, that enables plant biologists to build, validate, and use intuitive computer models, with a user interface that does not require mathematical or modeling expertise. No such tool is currently available.

PlantSimLab is intended to play the role of a virtual laboratory, in which plant biologists can interrogate a computational model in ways similar to how it is done in the laboratory. The software will be developed in close collaboration with the plant biology community, through use cases that drive software capabilities and interface features. Finally, an extensive dissemination effort will be made to introduce the tool to plant biologists. The project will also leverage an ongoing outreach project that engages 9-12 year-old children across Virginia. The program, Kids' Tech University (KTU), brings 450 children to the Virginia Tech campus 4 times each year, where they interact with scientists, participate in hands-on laboratories, and, between campus events, explore a virtual space related to topics discussed on campus. The project will result in hands-on as well as virtual activities related to plant biology in general and the focus of the proposed project in particular.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many molecular processes in plants are regulated by nonlinear dynamic networks of heterogeneous molecules, so that systems biology provides a valuable approach in this field, building on the integration of experimental biology with mathematical modeling. One of the biggest challenges to making this integration a reality is that many plant biologists do not possess the mathematical background needed to build and manipulate mathematical models well enough to use them as tools for hypothesis generation. Available software tools for network modeling are intended to be used primarily by modelers. The fundamental hypothesis underlying this project is that, with the right type of models and the right interface, biologists can construct, analyze, and use mathematical models for hypothesis generation, without direct assistance from modelers.

One of the major outcomes of this project is a software tool, PlantSimLab, which accomplishes these goals. It helps introduce computational thinking on a broad scale to plant biologists. Network modeling and systems biology are key tools in an effort to understand critical regulatory, signaling, and metabolic networks in plants as well as host-pathogen interactions and the immune response. Dynamic computer models of molecular networks serve several purposes. They provide a coherent conceptual framework to integrate and organize biological information from the literature and from experimental data. And they can serve as a virtual laboratory to interrogate the network and formulate testable biological hypotheses. Putting an easy-to-use tool like this in the hands of plant biologists, with an interface that focuses on biological instead of mathematical features, can help meet on of the big challenges we face: expand the plant biologist's tool kit to introduce computational thinking into the field. Thus, the project outcomes are likely to have a very significant and broad impact on the field of plant biology.

Another outcome of the project is an educational program that reached almost 300 children ages 9-12 and their parents, as part of the Virginia Tech outreach program Kids' Tech University. The program is designed to spark excitement in children about science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. One of the program events focused on plant biology and mathematics in the service of understanding the way in which plants fight diseases.
